natural problem: If $2x+7$ is a factor of $6x^3+19x^2+cx+35$, find $c$.
natural solution: Since $2x+7$ is a factor, we should get a remainder of $0$ when we divide $6x^3+19x^2+cx+35$. \[ \begin{array}{c|cccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{3x^2} & -x&+5  \\ \cline{2-5} 2x+7 & 6x^3&+19x^2&+cx&+35 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{-6x^3} & -21x^2  \\

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x c :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. 6 * x powr 3 + 19 * x powr 2 + c * x + 35 = (2 * x + 7) * f x"
shows  "c = 3"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If $2x+7$ is a factor of $6x^3+19x^2+cx+35$, find $c$. The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 Since $2x+7$ is a factor, we should get a remainder of $0$ when we divide $6x^3+19x^2+cx+35$. \[ \begin{array}{c|cccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{3x^2} & -x&+5  \\ \cline{2-5} 2x+7 & 6x^3&+19x^2&+cx&+35 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{-6x^3} & -21x^2  \\ 
 \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & -2x^2 & +cx  \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & +2x^2 & +7x \\  \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 & (c+7)x & + 35 \\  \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & -10x & -35 \\  \cline{4-5} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & (c+7-10)x & 0 \\ 
 \end{array} \]The remainder is $0$ if $c+7-10=0$, so $c=\boxed{3}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x c :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. 6 * x powr 3 + 19 * x powr 2 + c * x + 35 = (2 * x + 7) * f x"
shows  "c = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the value of $c$ that makes the cubic polynomial $6x^3 + 19x^2 + cx + 35$ equal to the product of $2x + 7$ and some function $f(x)$. The final answer is $c = 3$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x c :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 6 * x powr 3 + 19 * x powr 2 + c * x + 35"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x + 7"
and h2 : "P x dvd Q x"
shows  "c = 3"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If $2x+7$ is a factor of $6x^3+19x^2+cx+35$, find $c$. The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof

 \end{array} \]The remainder is $0$ if $c+7-10=0$, so $c=\boxed{3}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x c :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 6 * x powr 3 + 19 * x powr 2 + c * x + 35"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x + 7"
and h2 : "P x dvd Q x"
shows  "c = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the value of $c$ that makes the cubic polynomial $6x^3 + 19x^2 + cx + 35$ divisible by the linear polynomial $2x + 7$. The final Answer is $3$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x c :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"

and h2 : "P x dvd Q x"
shows  "c = 3"

theorem
fixes x c :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 6 * x powr 3 + 19 * x powr 2 + c * x + 35"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x + 7"
and h2 : "P x dvd Q x"
shows  "c = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the constant $c$ in the polynomial $P(x) = 6x^3 + 19x^2 + cx + 35$ such that for every $x$, $P(x)$ divides $Q(x) = 2x + 7$. The final answer is $c = 3$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x c :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 6 * x powr 3 + 19 * x powr 2 + c * x + 35"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x + 7"
and h2 : "P x dvd Q x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x"
shows  "c = 3"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If $2x+7$ is a factor of $6x^3+19x^2+cx+35$, find $c$. The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 Since $2x+7$ is a factor, we should get a remainder of $0$ when we divide $6x^3+19x^2+cx+35$. \[ \begin{array}{c|cccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{3x^2} & -x&+5  \\ \cline{2-5} 2x+7 & 6x^3&+19x^2&+cx&+35 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{-6x^3} & -21x^2  \\ 
 \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & -2x^2 & +cx  \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & +2x^2 & +7x \\  \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 & (c+7)x & + 35 \\  \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & -10x & -35 \\  \cline{4-5} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & (c+7-10)x & 0 \\ 
 \end{array} \]The remainder is $0$ if $c+7-10=0$, so $c=\boxed{3}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x c :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 6 * x powr 3 + 19 * x powr 2 + c * x + 35"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x + 7"
and h2 : "P x dvd Q x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x"
shows  "c = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given a polynomial $P(x) = 6x^3 + 19x^2 + cx + 35$ and another polynomial $Q(x) = 2x + 7$ such that $P(x)$ is a divisor of $Q(x)$ and $P(x)$ can be expressed as a product of $Q(x)$ and another polynomial $R(x)$, find the value of $c$. The final answer is $3$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes c :: real and f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = 6 * x powr 3 + 19 * x powr 2 + c * x + 35"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = 2 * x + 7"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. f x dvd g x"
shows  "c = 3"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 \end{array} \]The remainder is $0$ if $c+7-10=0$, so $c=\boxed{3}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes c :: real and f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = 6 * x powr 3 + 19 * x powr 2 + c * x + 35"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = 2 * x + 7"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. f x dvd g x"
shows  "c = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the value of $c$ such that the polynomial $f(x) = 6x^3 + 19x^2 + cx + 35$ is a divisor of the polynomial $g(x) = 2x + 7$. The final answer is $c = 3$.
